column2: the veneer is passed to the cutting table
column3: where it is cut to lengths and widths as desired. It is then conveyed to the second story
column4: where it is placed in large dry rooms
column6: except as the air reaches them through the proper channels. The veneer is here placed in crates
column7: each piece separate and standing on edge. The hot air is then turned on. This comes from the sheet iron furnace attached to the boiler in the engine room below
column8: and is conveyed through large pipes regulated by dampers for putting on or taking off the heat. There is also a blower attached which keeps the hot air in the dry rooms in constant motion
column9: the air as it cools passing off through an escape pipe in the roof
column10: while the freshly heated air takes its place from below. These rooms are also provided with a net-work of hot air pipes near the floor. The temperature is kept at about 165°
column11: and so rapid is the drying process that in the short space of four hours the green log from the steam box is shaved
